Does it make sense that f1(EvaluationAveraging) = f1(class 1) when having 2 classes?
Example: f1=0.650 class_0(f1)=0.398 class_1(f1)=0.650 f1
I believe it's normal for a binary classifer to only report the F1 of the "positive" class
ok, thanks
Although I thought that Evaluation always reported the average...
@syreal17  yes, I was surprised too that the evaluation does not give me an average of the two classes

Maybe it's a new feature? I had to be careful with recall and precision in a paper I'm writing because the reported recall was the average of 0 and 1, but looking at the confusion matrix, I could calculate a more commonly accepted recall/precision for a binary classifier
*class 0 and class 1
Oh cool man, that's good to know
I thought my training suddenly got way better
@fredfredfred  well it kind of did, because no one uses an average of F1_0 and F1_1 as F1 for a binary classifier. It's just F1_1

so underneath we do our own garbage collector with workspaces: https://deeplearning4j.org/workspaces
so sometimes there's a "warmup time" depending on how you configure it
when we allocate ndarrays, we use pinned cuda memory
that pinned memory is memory mapped on the cpu and gpu
workspaces minimizes allocations after it learns the patterns, the dual allocation + buffer reuse is the core of the garbage collector
everything we do is based on cuda streams for async loading of data and compute for max latency hiding (these are things you can google search)
So the GC is also working on the GPU memory ?
Or you allocate once and then it runs
no we GC/reuse via workspaces
your overhead may come from the data pipeline or the wrong workspaces configuration

again if you look at the differences between us and caffe, caffe forces that h5 format
whereas we just allow anything to happen
Using the python wrapper you can input numpy arrays

Hello! When it comes to learning rate, do we look for highest possible that will work or do we preffer a little bit lower one?
> It depends

Usually you'd want to start with the highest possible, and then reduce it, properly choosing the learning rate is as much of an art as any other hyperparameter tuning, as it massively affects whether your system will converge or not

basically using a too small one will not only result in many more iterations than is needed, but it may also put your network in a local minimum where it can't get out, yet a too large one may jump over the good solution
yeah.. so low learning rate is bad as it can get stuck in deep and narrow local minimum..
Problem with higher rates is that it cannot settle in global minimum right?
No, it's not.
May not settle...
Rather, with a high learning rate your system is likely to explode
@KolyaIvankov Yeah but you can know it by looking at score/iteration chart.. Problem is you cannot be sure when you choose too low value instead..
And indeed with a high learning rate your system is likely to dance around the extrema, but there is no warranty that your extremum is global.
hmmm okey
@MilanVanca If you'd like more information on the topic, I recommend looking up convex vs. non-convex optimization, in deep learning you are dealing with non-convex optimization

Hey guys, are LSTM's with TANH as activation still commonly used? Or is the GravesLSTM with SOFTSIGN simply 'a lot' better? Even though the dl4j site says TanH is still common, all examples use softsign and I cannot seem to find much of a difference in the final evaluation of these two myself.
use tanh, it's more standard
and it's not *all* examples, though it looks like it's been copy/pasted a bit
in practice they have pretty similar shapes anyway
I haven't seen any empirical comparison in the context of LSTMs
but softsign does outperform tanh in dense/fully connected nets
but there you should be using relus etc anyway

@raver119 @MrDallOca yes, learningRate(double) is gone, and that's intentional. As are all the schedule-related things on the main builder
instead: the only option is to use .updater(new Adam(learningRate)) etc
it's a bit of a transition, but it's much more reliable/robust
otherwise suppose you did .learningRate(x).updater(new Adam()) or .learningRate(x).updater(new Adam(y)) it's error prone / much less clear what is intended
not to mention that some updaters don't *have* learning rates at all

can anyone here expand on this line in the memory doc? "It’s not recommended to use HOST-only arrays directly, since they will dramatically reduce performance. But they might be useful as in-memory cache pairs with the INDArray.unsafeDuplication() method."

@Chrono7 what exactly you want explained?
@raver119 For starters, what does unsafeDuplication do, and if you use HOST-only, does it just copy INDArrays to the GPU when computing something?
for starters: do not touch that.
i can't explain GPU streaming or chessboarding for starters, sorry :/
unsafeDuplication - does memcpy basically.
so it's usable across multiple devices
but synchronization is your responsibility basically
so if I have a bunch of INDArrays that won't fit in my GPU but will fit in my CPU RAM, how should I store them off-GPU until they are needed on GPU for training?
there's multiple ways to do that.
you can do that via pointers, or via workspaces.

@raver119 I've been reading about workspaces so far. So basically I have a flow of images coming in and I want to convert them to INDArrays as they come in and store them for later training. Can I just process the image to an INDArray and detach it (hopefully putting it in CPU RAM?), and then later attach it for training?
@Chrono7 nah, detaching anything is bad idea. You should just have 2 workspaces. one cpu-only workspace
and another one is gpu-enabled workspace
and you'll use both as circular buffers
hmm @raver119 but I need to have JVM managed metadata / containing classes for the arrays as well.. what will happen if I detach them?
nothing.
so why is it a bad idea

double check the input and try to understand your neural net architecture
please do not just treat this as a magic black box
any random neural net architecture always has input constraints whether that be number of channels or otherwise

any random cnn ( I don't even know which one you're using) almost always has 4d input
try to understand what you are using and how to combine them by looking at and understanding their inputs
it really depends on what your intended problem is though
our video example basically does 1 frame at a time in to an lstm (starting with a cnn) - try to understand how we combine those

if you're using that api you're bound to be trying different kinds of nets
which is why I wanted to short circuit that and get you to look closer at the input :D

I'm personally just against you using transfer learning here because of the black box nature and high degree of customization you would need to do to bolt stacked LSTMs on to it (like the example)
you *can* but just understand the rabbit hole you're going down and if you still want to do it pick both the input and the architecture carefully
keep in mind it also depends what your input is vs your latter part of your neural net
if the error happens at layer 0 it's your input, if it happens in the middle it's your architecture

Maybe to bring it down to the "root" question I am having a hard time to understand: If I have multivariate time series with e.g. 5 channels and I want to classify them by detecting features across time AND across combinations of channel values ("correlations"), is it useful to build a dataset with dimensions x=sequence length and y=all possible permutations of combinations of two (or three,....) channels and then run a 2d cnn across time AND the permutations (with kernel size = to the number of channels the permutations are generated from) ? Does this help to capture the "cross-channel-and-time-patterns" or is a 1d cnn that runs "only" across time, equivalent in terms of the expected learning effect? Hope my question is clear?

a 1d CNN is able to learn the sort of correlations you want to learn
or put another way, the 1D CNN won't have greater representational/learning power by manually duplicating and permuting data channels
the order/layout of the channels doesn't matter (for example, a 2D CNN can learn equally well with RGB, BGR, GRB, etc layout for the color channels)

Anyone implemented "Temperature Scaling" to calibrate a neural network? How to do that in dl4j?
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1706.04599.pdf
http://alondaks.com/2017/12/31/the-importance-of-calibrating-your-deep-model/

@stolsvik nothing built in for correcting calibration (there's an issue open for platt scaling and isotonic regression for binary classification)
we do have classification calibration evaluation (see https://deeplearning4j.org/docs/latest/deeplearning4j-nn-evaluation )
as for temperature scaling - no, but it's basically a scaled/weighted softmax... so one simple approach is to either get the last layer's activations (pre softmax, assuming you are using a loss layer) and apply it manually, or swap out the output layer softmax with a custom activation function that implements it. Though either way you still have the optimization aspect for the temperature parameter (but again, not too hard in theory...)
Edit: issue here, but we probabyl won't get to it in the very near future https://github.com/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j/issues/6961

@AlexDBlack Oh, nice evaluator! Can such a thing be used for multi-label too, or is it only multi-class?
Wrt. how difficult - the paper brags that it is basically just a few lines. There's an implementations for PyTorch: https://github.com/gpleiss/temperature_scaling/blob/master/temperature_scaling.py

so if I have `.setInputTypes(InputType.convolutionalFlat(6, 6, 2))` - do I still need to tell the first convlayer that it gets 2 layers as input like this: `.addLayer("cnn1",  new ConvolutionLayer.Builder(new int[]{3, 3}, new int[]{1, 1}, new int[]{0,0}).convolutionMode(ConvolutionMode.Same).nIn(2).nOut(8).activation( Activation.RELU).build(), "board")`? and it will give me 8 output layers of the same size (6x6) as the input?

@threepwoody you don't need to set nIn(2) manually there - that's the point of setInputType. You only need to specify the network input (once) not the input for every layer (as that has to match the activations into each layer - which we can infer automatically if we only known the overall net input type)

> 8 output layers

that's bad terminology... it'll give you *1* conovlutional layer, with depth/channels set to 8
as for "same size as input" - yeah
output sizes are explained in ConvolutionMode javadoc
for ConvolutionMode.Same it's inputSize/stride
so with stride = 1, output size is same as input size

SubsetVertex seems to imply it is the same as the input shape?
yeah, it's *always* an identical shape to the input
it has to be, by definition: it's the dL/dIn, where L is the loss function
ah, so where is the shape of epsilon set, the next layer?

not sure I'm following your question
but keep in mind we always have 2 activation gradients (epsilons): those from the layer above (passed as arg to backprop method) and those to be passed to layer below (returned from backprop method)
the ones from layer above match the layer output shape
the returned ones match the layer input shape

ohh so for my repeat vertex [x] --> [x,x,x,x], I need to propagate up an output (the gradient) [o] <-- given an epsilon from below [e,e,e,e]... I think. So would it make sense to just sum the epsilons and pass that up?

if forward pass is [x] --> [x,x,x,x]
then backward pass is [e] <- [e,e,e,e]
you get epsilons from the layer above, and pass them to layer below
backward pass for your case should just be a sum along dimension 1

Hi everyone. I'm trying to use DL4J for image segmentation but I'm having some trouble finding good examples online. I have previously used DL4J for image classification and time series data regression with good results, so it's not just that I'm a novice. I have implemented a smaller version of the zoo model UNET but the network does not seem to converge, not even on the training data. I have implemented my own PathLabelGenerator which generates a label from an image with the same name as the feature image, but placed in another folder.  The label is a binary label, i. e. 1 for every pixel of interest. I've tried various activation functions and loss functions in the cnnlosslayer, and different activation functions in the last cnn layer with no success. Any help is much appreciated. Best regards. Btw: first time on gitter, so if this has already been discussed I apologize. I couldn't find anything with the search function.

@emildb 
> I've tried various activation functions and loss functions in the cnnlosslayer, and different activation functions in the last cnn layer with no success

there's not much you should be trying here, there's only really 2 valid CnnLossLayer configurations for segmentation:
for binary segmentation (output/labels shape [n,1,h,w]) you want sigmoid + xent, with labels being 0 or 1 for each pixel
for multi-class segmentation (output/labels shape [n,C,h,w] for C classes) you want softmax + mcxent, with a one-hot vector along channels, for each x/y location

is that what you used?
don't forget the usual things - normalization of the input, and tuning of the learning rate etc

@AlexDBlack I tried both sigmoid + xent with relu in the last cnn layer, identity + xent with sigmoid in the last cnn layer and softmax + mcxent with sigmoid in the last cnn layer (as the unet example model). My label has a shape [n,1,h,w] with labels being 0 or 1 for each pixel, so should it be sigmoid + xent with relu in the last cnn layer or identity + xent with sigmoid in the last cnn layer? (The former seems to not converge at all, so I guess the latter is correct?)
I have double-checked the normalization and tried different updaters. Maybe it's just that the model is not large enough and/or it needs more time to train before it produces any sensible output. I will investigate further. Cheers.

> so should it be sigmoid + xent with relu in the last cnn layer or identity + xent with sigmoid in the last cnn layer

think about what the former is doing... you're literally applying 2 activation functions on the same output activations, which is a bad idea
it should be identity on last conv layer + sigmoid/xent on the loss layer, for the [n,1,h,w] case
though that's equivalent to sigmoid + identity/xent in this particular case

> for multi-class segmentation the case is sigmoid + softmax/mcxent,

that's incorrect, and won't learn well (if at all). So no, there's no exception. You want identidy on the last conv + softmax/mcxent in that case

>  would it not be correct to say that the binary segmentation is a special case of multi-class segmentation, so it would be possible to make two label maps: the one I have and one where the values are inverted, and train it as a multi-class segmentation network?

yes, exactly. You should get the same result is you convert your [n,1,h,w] to [n,2,h,w] (with one-hot along channels per x/y location for the labels) and switch to softmax/mcxent

> The reason I ask is that it would be nice with a binary output instead of the continuous one

the output is a probability, and has to be a probability for the loss functions to make sense
so yes, you need to apply a decision threshold to get an actual class prediction from the probability distribution

so
this is _almost_ 1.0 and 0.0 respectively
and INDArray.toString() applies formatting
so you get 1.0 and 0.0 printed out
because you get 0.9999999 and 0.000001 as probabilities
if you want to get these values without formatting - you could just print them out as scalars
